attributes.title: Elevated Plasmodium sporozoite infection and multiple insecticide resistance in the principal malaria vectors Anopheles funestus and Anopheles gambiae in a forested locality close to the airport of Yaoundé, the Capital city of Cameroon
attributes.description: Our project characterized malaria vectors in a locality near the Yaounde international airport, the capital city of Cameroon, including species composition, abundance, Plasmodium infection rate; insecticide resistance profiles and underlying resistance mechanisms.

summary.value: This summarizes the data obtained during analysis of the credible outcomes (results) of the research

attributes.title: Ambiguity in Justice Events

q1.value: Irina Cojuharenco, Tatiana Marques, David Patient, João Barreiros

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Participants will answer questions regarding all 8 scenarios of a 2 (high vs. low distributive justice) X 2 (high vs. low procedural justice) X 2 (high vs. low interactional justice) between-subjects design.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of our eight conditions (the randomization is automatically done by Qualtrics software).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited online through Amazon Mechanical Turk to respond to a questionnaire. They will be paid $1.00 for participation (the study is expected to take 10 minutes on average). Participants will be excluded due to inattentiveness (prior to any manipulation). Our data collection should start in April 2020.

q11.value: We expect to collect 230 (200 + 15% due to inattentiveness) valid responses.

q12.value: We conducted power analysis using G*Power 3.1 (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009). For testing H1, we computed the required sample size for an a-priori t-test of the difference between the mean score of justice ambiguity index, and a constant value – the mid-point of the scale (3,5), for each of the conditions. For the estimation we entered a power of 80%, a large effect size (d=.80), and an error probability to be 10% significance (because it is one-tailed). The required sample size is 8 per condition (8*8=64). We also we computed the required sample size for an a-priori F-test in a one-way ANOVA to be powered at 80% with a large effect size (f=.040), with Bonferroni adjustment with error probability to be 5% significance divided by 8 which is the number of conditions we have (0.05/8= 0.00625).  The required sample size is 144. For testing H2, we computed the required sample size for an a-priori t-test of the difference between the mean scores of overall justice clarity index, distributive justice clarity index, procedural justice clarity index and interactional justice clarity index, and a constant value – the mid-point of the scale (3,5). For the estimation we entered a power of 80% and a large effect size (d=.05), and an error probability to be 10% significance (because it is one-tailed). The required sample size is 8 per condition (8*8=64). For testing H3, we should have a minimum of 200 participants to run the CFA (Jackson, 2001).

q13.value: Set by Amazon Mechanical Turk when the specified sample size is reached.

question.value:
Participants will first respond to the justice ambiguity scale, in which they are asked the extent to which they agree with the statements, on a scale ranging from 1 - Strongly disagree to 7 – Strongly agree:
1. It was difficult for me to judge whether I was treated fairly in this situation. [ja_1]
2. The situation was ambiguous in terms of fairness. [ja_2]
3. It was uncertain whether I was treated fairly or unfairly. [ja_3]
Secondly, participants will respond to the overall event justice scale, also by expressing the extent to which they agree with the following sentences (1 – Strongly disagree to 7 – Strongly agree):
1. Overall, I was treated fairly in this situation. [oej_1]
2. Overall, I can count on this organization to be fair with promotions. [oej_2]
3. In this situation, the treatment I received was fair. [oej_3]
Thirdly, participants will respond to the justice clarity scale (1 – Strongly disagree to 7 – Strongly agree):
1. In the above situation, I know clearly whether the promotion decision reflects the effort I have put into my work. [jc_1]
2. In the above situation, I know clearly whether the promotion decision is appropriate for the work I have completed. [jc_2]
3. In the above situation, I know clearly whether the promotion decision reflects what I have contributed to the organization. [jc_3]
4. In the above situation, I know clearly whether I am able to express my views and feelings during those procedures used to determine promotions. [jc_4]
5. In the above situation, I know clearly whether those procedures used to determine promotions have been applied consistently. [jc_5]
6. In the above situation, I know clearly whether those procedures used to determine promotions have been free of bias. [jc_6]
7. In the above situation, I know clearly whether the supervisor was able to suppress personal biases regarding the promotion decision. [jc_7]
8. In the above situation, I know clearly whether the supervisor showed concern for my rights as worker regarding the promotion decision. [jc_8]
9. In the above situation, I know clearly whether the supervisor took steps to deal with me in a truthful manner regarding the promotion decision. [jc_9]
Fourthly, participants will respond to the organizational citizenship behaviors towards the organization and supervisor scales (OCBO and OCBS), by indicating how frequently (from 1 – Never to 7 – Very often) they believe would engage in the following behaviors, in the immediate aftermath of the situation described in the scenario?
1. Willingly give your time to help your supervisor with work-related problems. [ocb_1]
2. Adjust your work schedule to accommodate your supervisor’s requests for time off. [ocb_2]
3. Show genuine concern and courtesy toward your supervisor, even under the most trying business or personal situations. [ocb_3]
4. Give up time to help your supervisor with work or nonwork problems. [ocb_4]
5. Assist your supervisor with his/her duties. [ocb_5]
6. Attend functions that are not required but that help the organizational image. [ocb_6]
7. Keep up with developments in the organization. [ocb_7]
8. Defend the organization when other employees criticize it. [ocb_8]
9. Show pride when representing the organization in public. [ocb_9]
10. Offer ideas to improve the functioning of the organization. [ocb_10]
11. Express loyalty toward the organization. [ocb_11]
12. Take action to protect the organization from potential problems. [ocb_12]
13. Demonstrate concern about the image of the organization. [ocb_13]
Finally, participants will be asked to indicate the extent to which they accept the decision made, (in a scale from 1 – Strongly disagree to 7 – Strongly agree):
1. I find the decision that was communicated acceptable. [da_1]
2. I support the promotion decision. [da_2]
3. I accept the promotion decision. [da_3]

Cronbach’s alpha will be used to examine the reliability of all the scales. We will create indices of each scale by computing the means of each scale’s scores, as follows:
•	Justice ambiguity index: new variable [just_amb] = mean of the items [ja_1], [ja_2], and [ja_3]
•	Overall event justice index: new variable [overJust] = mean of the items [oej_1], [oej_2], and [oej_3]
•	Overall justice clarity index: new variable [just_cla] = mean of the items [jc_1], [jc_2], [jc_3], [jc_4], [jc_5], [jc_6], [jc_7], [jc_8], [jc_9]
•	Distributive justice clarity index: new variable [DJ_cla] = mean of the items [jc_1], [jc_2], and [jc_3]
•	Procedural justice clarity index: new variable [PJ_cla] = mean of the items [jc_4], [jc_5], [jc_6], [jc_7], [jc_8], and [jc_9]
•	Interactional justice clarity index: new variable [IJ_cla] = mean of the items [jc_7], [jc_8], and [jc_9]
•	Organizational citizenship behaviors towards the supervisor index: [ocbs] = mean of the items [ocb_1], [ocb_2], [ocb_3], [ocb_4], and [ocb_5]
•	Organizational citizenship behaviors towards the organization index: [ocbo] = mean of the items [ocb_6], [ocb_7], [ocb_8], [ocb_9], [ocb_10], [ocb_11], [ocb_12], and [ocb_13]
•	Decision acceptance index: [dec_acc] = mean of the items [da_1], [da_2], and [da_3]

We will first create a variable whose values correspond to each experimental condition (i.e., 1=high distributive justice/ high procedural justice / high interactional justice; 2=high distributive justice/ high procedural justice / low interactional justice; 3=high distributive justice/ low procedural justice / high interactional justice; 4=high distributive justice/ low procedural justice / low interactional justice; 5= low distributive justice/ low procedural justice / low interactional justice; 6=low distributive justice/ high procedural justice / high interactional justice; 7=low distributive justice/ high procedural justice / low interactional justice; 8=low distributive justice/ low procedural justice / high interactional justice). For testing H1, we will we will run eight one-sample t-tests comparing the overall justice ambiguity index ([just_amb] variable) of all eight conditions to the mid-point of the scale (3,5). We will also run a one-way ANOVA analysis comparing justice ambiguity index scores ([just_amb] variable) between conditions, and run contrasts between the conditions. The condition with higher justice ambiguity will be used in a follow-up study. For testing H2, we will run eight one sample t-tests comparing the overall justice clarity index ([just_cla] variable) of all eight conditions to the mid-point of the scale (3,5). For testing H3, we will 1) compute the Cronbach’s alpha for justice ambiguity, justice clarity, overall event justice, decision acceptance, OCB towards the supervisor and OCB towards the organization, which should all be >.7, and 2) perform a confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) which should confirm an eight-factor structure: justice ambiguity, distributive justice clarity, interactional justice clarity, procedural justice clarity, decision acceptance, OCB towards the supervisor and OCB towards the organization.

q20.value:
We will remove from the analyses participants who meet any of the following criteria:
•	Spend less time reading the presented scenario, by 2 standard deviations or more;
•	Repeat the IP address (case in which we will exclude all but the first responses of a given IP address).
•	Participants will be excluded due to inattentiveness (prior to any manipulation) based on a question about the frequency of brushing teeth with a suggested response option (excluded=suggestion not followed, included=suggested response given).

q21.value: Participants with missing data will not be included in the analyses.

attributes.title: Citizens’ Perspectives on Public Service Delivery: A Survey Experiment on Public-Private Partnerships in Germany - Study 2

q1.value: Citizens’ Perspectives on Public Service Delivery A Survey Experiment on Public-Private Partnerships in Germany – Study 2

q3.value:
Research Questions:
1)	Which influence does public-private collaboration have on perceived legitimacy of the involved public administration?

2)	Which influence does success, respectively failure, of public-private collaboration have on perceived legitimacy of the involved public administration

3)	How does citizens’ perceived legitimacy with respect to private organizations influence their perceived legitimacy toward public administrations in the context of public-private collaboration?  

To study these questions, we will conduct a survey experiment (2 x 3 mixed factorial design) in which participants will be confronted with vignettes specifying the public service delivery context (construction and management of a penal institution). The content of the vignettes differs by the mode of service delivery (public-private collaboration / public agency alone) as well as the project’s success (success / neutral / failure). The experimental vignettes will be:

-	Vignette A: public-private collaboration, successful
-	Vignette B: public agency alone, successful
-	Vignette C: public-private collaboration, neutral
-	Vignette D: public agency alone, neutral
-	Vignette E: public-private collaboration, unsuccessful
-	Vignette F: public agency alone, unsuccessful

Prior to this experimental design, we will assess the participants’ perceptions of legitimacy after presenting two short vignettes outlining both the public and private organization.

q4.value:
H1: Public service delivery by means of public-private collaboration with a private company will decrease the legitimacy of the involved public administration as perceived by the citizens, compared to the delivery through the public administration alone.

H2a: The successful provision of the public service project will increase legitimacy of the involved public administrations as perceived by the citizens, compared to undefined project performance.
H2b: This effect will be weaker if the project is conducted by means of public-private collaboration compared to the service delivery by the public administration alone.

H3a: The unsuccessful provision of the public service project will decrease legitimacy of the involved public administrations, as perceived by the citizens, compared to undefined project performance.
H3b: This effect will be stronger if the project is conducted by means of public-private collaboration compared to the service delivery by the public administration alone.

H4: The change of the legitimacy of the involved public administration, as perceived by the citizens, will be stronger in the case of public-private collaboration, compared to public service delivery by the public administration alone.

H5: The involvement of the private company in the public service project will decrease legitimacy of the private company, as perceived by the citizens, in the case of public-private collaboration.

H6: The change of the legitimacy of the private company, as perceived by the citizens, will be negatively correlated with the legitimacy of the public administration, as perceived by the citizens, in the case of public-private collaboration.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2 by 3 mixed factorial design

q9.value: Randomization will be done after participants have read the starting page and agreed to participate. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the six experimental vignettes after following the personalized invitation link. Randomization will be ensured using the survey tool’s (SoSci Survey) randomization mechanism (uniformly distributed drawing).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited via a commercial panel provider in Germany. The service provider will ensure a representative sample (age and gender) for the population in the federal state of Baden-Württemberg. 

The study is designed as a survey experiment. Participants followed a double-opt-in-registration at the panel provider. Each individual in the panel has a personalized interface on the provider’s homepage. Here, invitations to surveys are specified including a detailed description of the study containing all necessary information for informed consent. Furthermore, participants are invited through e-mail communication hosted by the panel provider. If the participants agree to participate, they will be forwarded to the survey. Participants will receive a payment if they complete the study.

q13.value: We aim for a minimum sample size of 651 participants who will be randomized into one of six groups.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis assuming a small to medium sized effect of f = 0.15 (alpha = 0.05; power = 0.8532; ANOVA, fixed effects, special, main effects and interactions), resulting in a required minimum sample size of n = 651.

q15.value: The invitation to participate in the study will be sent to participants in the panel living in the federal state of Baden-Württemberg. The distribution of invitation follows the providers sampling strategy and ensures representativeness with regard to age and gender of the participants. Assuming 30 % failed attention checks and a lack of control regarding the participations, we will aim for an overall sample of n = 1000. This threshold emerges from a more conservative power analysis assuming very small sized effects of f = 0.10 (alpha = 0.05; power = 0.8532; ANOVA, fixed effects, special, main effects and interactions) resulting in a proposed sample size of 1456. By following this approach, we avoid potential waste of resources and an overpowered study, while still addressing small effects that might be present in the study.

question.value:
The study uses an experimental design within a survey study. Participants are randomly assigned to one out of six different vignettes. The vignettes display a realistic – non judgmental – newspaper article reporting a public service project (construction and management of a penal institution). These articles are identical except for the type of service delivery (public-private collaboration / public agency alone) and the projects’ performance (success / neutral / unsuccessful) outlined.

-	Vignette A: public-private partnership, successful
-	Vignette B: public agency alone, successful
-	Vignette C: public-private collaboration, neutral
-	Vignette D: public agency alone, neutral
-	Vignette E: public-private collaboration, unsuccessful
-	Vignette F: public agency alone, unsuccessful

The full wording of the vignettes is appended (Appendix C).

In order to obtain comparisons of participant’s perceptions of organizational legitimacy (both regarding the public and the private organization displayed) each participant will provide an initial assessment of legitimacy perceptions for the public and private organizations before receiving the treatment. The participants will indicate their rating for the pre-measurement variables after being introduced to both organizations separately. This approach is promising to obtain pretest-posttest comparisons which offer significant advantages regarding the data’s explanatory power as well as regarding the analysis (Aguinis and Bradley 2014).

To avoid priming or anchoring effects through the pretest-posttest design we integrate a distraction task into the questionnaire. The distraction task contains another experiment which deviates from the study’s focus on legitimacy. Instead, participants receive an announcement from the public organization (ministry of justice, Baden-Württemberg) specifying the need for voluntary actions in the judicial system of Baden-Württemberg. In this experiment, we varied the gender representativeness within the announcement following Riccucci, Van Ryzin, and Li (2016) and Van Ryzin, Riccucci, and Li (2017), to analyze participant’s willingness to volunteer. The distraction experiment is specified in detail in a separate pre-registration.

Aguinis, Herman, and Kyle J. Bradley. 2014. “Best Practice Recommendations for Designing and Implementing Experimental Vignette Methodology Studies.” Organizational Research Methods 17 (4): 351–71. doi:10.1177/1094428114547952.

Riccucci, Norma M., Gregg G. Van Ryzin, and Huafang Li. 2016. “Representative Bureaucracy and the Willingness to Coproduce: An Experimental Study.” Public Administration Review 76 (1): 121–30. doi:10.1111/puar.12401.

Ryzin, Gregg G. Van, Norma M. Riccucci, and Huafang Li. 2017. “Representative Bureaucracy and Its Symbolic Effect on Citizens: A Conceptual Replication.” Public Management Review 19 (9): 1365–79. doi:10.1080/14719037.2016.1195009.
See Appendix B.
The items used to assess the variables will be combined to a mean index: Items might be dropped if Cronbach’s Alpha is below 0.7.

Step 1: Estimate an OLS regression model using legitimacy (post-measure) (of the involved public agency) as the dependent variable, and dummy variables for condition 1 (public-private collaboration / public agency alone) and condition 2 (success / neutral /unsuccessful) as independent variables (assessment of H1, H2a, H3a). Additionally, control variables (age, gender, educational level, workforce grouping, political orientation, and PSM, legitimacy pre-measurement) are added to the models as further independent variables. (H1, H2a, H3a)

Step 2: Add an additional OLS regression model that includes two interaction terms considering the moderating effects of condition 1 (public-private collaboration / public agency alone) regarding the influence of condition 2 (success / neutral / unsuccessful) on the dependent variables (H2b, H3b).

Step 3: Calculate the change of legitimacy of the public administration, as perceived by the citizens, before and after seeing the vignettes. Conduct an independent t-test comparing the difference between treatment and control group (public agency alone / public-private collaboration) with respect to this change (H4).

Step 4: Robustness Check: Including participants that failed the attention check using a dummy variable to all models.

Step 5: Reduce the dataset to obtain a subsample containing the experiment groups with the vignettes that indicated a public-private collaboration (involvement of both the public and private organization):

-	Vignette A: public-private partnership, successful
-	Vignette C: public-private partnership, neutral
-	Vignette E: public-private partnership, unsuccessful

Step 6: Conduct a dependent t-test comparing the difference between pre- and post-legitimacy assessment of the private organization (H5).

Step 7: Calculate the change of legitimacy of the private company, as perceived by the citizens, before and after seeing the vignettes. Estimate OLS regression model using legitimacy (post-measure) (of the involved public administration), and the change of the private organization’s legitimacy, as perceived by the citizens, as an independent variable. Additionally, control variables (age, gender, educational level, workforce grouping, political orientation, and PSM, legitimacy pre-measurement (public administration) are added to the model as further independent variables. (H6)

Furthermore, additional OLS regression models will assess the potential effect of pretest-measures on posttest-measures of organizational legitimacy concerning both organizations displayed in the experimental vignettes. 

Finally, additional OLS regression models will specify the correlation between legitimacy ∆ (changes between pretest and posttest-measures)

We will use the measured control variables to test their impact on the dependent variables as well as their moderation effects.

registration_responses.q1: Citizens’ Perspectives on Public Service Delivery A Survey Experiment on Public-Private Partnerships in Germany – Study 2
registration_responses.q3:
Research Questions:
1)	Which influence does public-private collaboration have on perceived legitimacy of the involved public administration?

2)	Which influence does success, respectively failure, of public-private collaboration have on perceived legitimacy of the involved public administration

3)	How does citizens’ perceived legitimacy with respect to private organizations influence their perceived legitimacy toward public administrations in the context of public-private collaboration?  

To study these questions, we will conduct a survey experiment (2 x 3 mixed factorial design) in which participants will be confronted with vignettes specifying the public service delivery context (construction and management of a penal institution). The content of the vignettes differs by the mode of service delivery (public-private collaboration / public agency alone) as well as the project’s success (success / neutral / failure). The experimental vignettes will be:

-	Vignette A: public-private collaboration, successful
-	Vignette B: public agency alone, successful
-	Vignette C: public-private collaboration, neutral
-	Vignette D: public agency alone, neutral
-	Vignette E: public-private collaboration, unsuccessful
-	Vignette F: public agency alone, unsuccessful

Prior to this experimental design, we will assess the participants’ perceptions of legitimacy after presenting two short vignettes outlining both the public and private organization.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: Public service delivery by means of public-private collaboration with a private company will decrease the legitimacy of the involved public administration as perceived by the citizens, compared to the delivery through the public administration alone.

H2a: The successful provision of the public service project will increase legitimacy of the involved public administrations as perceived by the citizens, compared to undefined project performance.
H2b: This effect will be weaker if the project is conducted by means of public-private collaboration compared to the service delivery by the public administration alone.

H3a: The unsuccessful provision of the public service project will decrease legitimacy of the involved public administrations, as perceived by the citizens, compared to undefined project performance.
H3b: This effect will be stronger if the project is conducted by means of public-private collaboration compared to the service delivery by the public administration alone.

H4: The change of the legitimacy of the involved public administration, as perceived by the citizens, will be stronger in the case of public-private collaboration, compared to public service delivery by the public administration alone.

H5: The involvement of the private company in the public service project will decrease legitimacy of the private company, as perceived by the citizens, in the case of public-private collaboration.

H6: The change of the legitimacy of the private company, as perceived by the citizens, will be negatively correlated with the legitimacy of the public administration, as perceived by the citizens, in the case of public-private collaboration.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Randomization will be done after participants have read the starting page and agreed to participate. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the six experimental vignettes after following the personalized invitation link. Randomization will be ensured using the survey tool’s (SoSci Survey) randomization mechanism (uniformly distributed drawing).
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We aim for a minimum sample size of 651 participants who will be randomized into one of six groups.
registration_responses.q14: We conducted a power analysis assuming a small to medium sized effect of f = 0.15 (alpha = 0.05; power = 0.8532; ANOVA, fixed effects, special, main effects and interactions), resulting in a required minimum sample size of n = 651.
registration_responses.q15: The invitation to participate in the study will be sent to participants in the panel living in the federal state of Baden-Württemberg. The distribution of invitation follows the providers sampling strategy and ensures representativeness with regard to age and gender of the participants. Assuming 30 % failed attention checks and a lack of control regarding the participations, we will aim for an overall sample of n = 1000. This threshold emerges from a more conservative power analysis assuming very small sized effects of f = 0.10 (alpha = 0.05; power = 0.8532; ANOVA, fixed effects, special, main effects and interactions) resulting in a proposed sample size of 1456. By following this approach, we avoid potential waste of resources and an overpowered study, while still addressing small effects that might be present in the study.

registration_responses.q8.question: 2 by 3 mixed factorial design
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited via a commercial panel provider in Germany. The service provider will ensure a representative sample (age and gender) for the population in the federal state of Baden-Württemberg. 

The study is designed as a survey experiment. Participants followed a double-opt-in-registration at the panel provider. Each individual in the panel has a personalized interface on the provider’s homepage. Here, invitations to surveys are specified including a detailed description of the study containing all necessary information for informed consent. Furthermore, participants are invited through e-mail communication hosted by the panel provider. If the participants agree to participate, they will be forwarded to the survey. Participants will receive a payment if they complete the study.
registration_responses.q16.question:
The study uses an experimental design within a survey study. Participants are randomly assigned to one out of six different vignettes. The vignettes display a realistic – non judgmental – newspaper article reporting a public service project (construction and management of a penal institution). These articles are identical except for the type of service delivery (public-private collaboration / public agency alone) and the projects’ performance (success / neutral / unsuccessful) outlined.

-	Vignette A: public-private partnership, successful
-	Vignette B: public agency alone, successful
-	Vignette C: public-private collaboration, neutral
-	Vignette D: public agency alone, neutral
-	Vignette E: public-private collaboration, unsuccessful
-	Vignette F: public agency alone, unsuccessful

The full wording of the vignettes is appended (Appendix C).

In order to obtain comparisons of participant’s perceptions of organizational legitimacy (both regarding the public and the private organization displayed) each participant will provide an initial assessment of legitimacy perceptions for the public and private organizations before receiving the treatment. The participants will indicate their rating for the pre-measurement variables after being introduced to both organizations separately. This approach is promising to obtain pretest-posttest comparisons which offer significant advantages regarding the data’s explanatory power as well as regarding the analysis (Aguinis and Bradley 2014).

To avoid priming or anchoring effects through the pretest-posttest design we integrate a distraction task into the questionnaire. The distraction task contains another experiment which deviates from the study’s focus on legitimacy. Instead, participants receive an announcement from the public organization (ministry of justice, Baden-Württemberg) specifying the need for voluntary actions in the judicial system of Baden-Württemberg. In this experiment, we varied the gender representativeness within the announcement following Riccucci, Van Ryzin, and Li (2016) and Van Ryzin, Riccucci, and Li (2017), to analyze participant’s willingness to volunteer. The distraction experiment is specified in detail in a separate pre-registration.

Aguinis, Herman, and Kyle J. Bradley. 2014. “Best Practice Recommendations for Designing and Implementing Experimental Vignette Methodology Studies.” Organizational Research Methods 17 (4): 351–71. doi:10.1177/1094428114547952.

Riccucci, Norma M., Gregg G. Van Ryzin, and Huafang Li. 2016. “Representative Bureaucracy and the Willingness to Coproduce: An Experimental Study.” Public Administration Review 76 (1): 121–30. doi:10.1111/puar.12401.

Ryzin, Gregg G. Van, Norma M. Riccucci, and Huafang Li. 2017. “Representative Bureaucracy and Its Symbolic Effect on Citizens: A Conceptual Replication.” Public Management Review 19 (9): 1365–79. doi:10.1080/14719037.2016.1195009.
registration_responses.q17.question: See Appendix B.
registration_responses.q18.question: The items used to assess the variables will be combined to a mean index: Items might be dropped if Cronbach’s Alpha is below 0.7.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Step 1: Estimate an OLS regression model using legitimacy (post-measure) (of the involved public agency) as the dependent variable, and dummy variables for condition 1 (public-private collaboration / public agency alone) and condition 2 (success / neutral /unsuccessful) as independent variables (assessment of H1, H2a, H3a). Additionally, control variables (age, gender, educational level, workforce grouping, political orientation, and PSM, legitimacy pre-measurement) are added to the models as further independent variables. (H1, H2a, H3a)

Step 2: Add an additional OLS regression model that includes two interaction terms considering the moderating effects of condition 1 (public-private collaboration / public agency alone) regarding the influence of condition 2 (success / neutral / unsuccessful) on the dependent variables (H2b, H3b).

Step 3: Calculate the change of legitimacy of the public administration, as perceived by the citizens, before and after seeing the vignettes. Conduct an independent t-test comparing the difference between treatment and control group (public agency alone / public-private collaboration) with respect to this change (H4).

Step 4: Robustness Check: Including participants that failed the attention check using a dummy variable to all models.

Step 5: Reduce the dataset to obtain a subsample containing the experiment groups with the vignettes that indicated a public-private collaboration (involvement of both the public and private organization):

-	Vignette A: public-private partnership, successful
-	Vignette C: public-private partnership, neutral
-	Vignette E: public-private partnership, unsuccessful

Step 6: Conduct a dependent t-test comparing the difference between pre- and post-legitimacy assessment of the private organization (H5).

Step 7: Calculate the change of legitimacy of the private company, as perceived by the citizens, before and after seeing the vignettes. Estimate OLS regression model using legitimacy (post-measure) (of the involved public administration), and the change of the private organization’s legitimacy, as perceived by the citizens, as an independent variable. Additionally, control variables (age, gender, educational level, workforce grouping, political orientation, and PSM, legitimacy pre-measurement (public administration) are added to the model as further independent variables. (H6)

q1.value: Felicitas Knape, Chiara Jutzi, Jochim Hansen

q2.value:
H1 (directional): Temporal distance interacts with a cause-vs-consequence focus on ease of generation. That is, temporal proximity (versus distance) leads to a higher ease of generation of consequences than of causes.

H2 (directional): Temporal distance interacts with generating causes versus consequences on risk perception and risk taking. That is, generation of proximal consequences (versus proximal causes) increases subjective seriousness of the pandemia and reduces risk behavior, compared to generation of distal consequences (versus distal causes).

H3 (directional): If H1 and H2 are supported by the data, ease of generation mediates the interaction effect of temporal distance and cause-vs-consequence focus on risk perception and risk taking is mediated by ease of generation.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: The data will be collected online. Therefore, there is no personnel who interacts directly with the study subjects. Thus, the personnel (although not interacting with the subjects) who administers the study online will not be aware of the assigned treatments. Thus, the study can be described as double blind.

question.value:
We have a full between-subjects 2 x 2 factorial design:
        	First factor (2 levels) = temporal proximal vs temporal distant
        	Second factor (2 levels) = generation of causes vs. generation of effects
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four combinations of the two factors.

q7.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined blocks. The randomization will be automatically created by Qualtrics, the software with which the study was created.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited mainly in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland through online promotion. Participants will not get any payment in form of money. Students studying psychology at the University of Salzburg (Austria) can receive 0,5 experience-credits for the participation in empirical-psychological investigations. Participants must be at least 18 years old and be fluent in German language.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 300 participants (75 participants in each of the four groups). This includes the assumption of a 20% drop-out rate of 60 participants, so that there will be at least about 240 participants (60 participants in each of the four groups).

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of Hedges g = .475 (i.e, the meta-analytic mean effect size of effects of psychological distance, see Söderberg et al., 2014) with the standard .05 alpha error probability. Analyses revealed a sample size of 233 participants. Expected drop-out rates of about 60 participants lead to a rounded number of 300 participants.

question.value:
We will manipulate temporal distance. Participants will be asked to imagine the Corona pandemia at the moment (temporally near) or at its assumed peak in a few weeks or months (temporally distant).
Additionally, we will manipulate a focus on causes versus consequences. Participants will be asked to generate either three causes of the pandemia or three consequences of the pandemia.

One outcome variable will be the ease of generation of causes (consequences). After participants generated either three causes or three consequences of the coronavirus pandemia, they will be asked to rate on a scale from 0 to 100 how easy it was to generate the causes (consequences) and how easy it would be to generate more causes (consequences).

The other outcome variables will be the risk perception and risk behavior concerning the coronavirus. Participants will be asked to rate their attitude to five questions concerning the risk (risk perception) and the adopted measures taken to contain the virus (risk behavior), on a scale from -5 to +5.
Ease of generation will be tested as mediator for the effects of the distance x causes-vs-consequences focus interaction on risk perception and risk behavior.  

Moreover, participants will be asked to rate the probability of ten scenarios, concerning the general risk perception for the population of one’s country on a scale from 0-100%.

We will test H1 and H2 with separate 2x2 ANOVAS. We predict interactions of distance and focus on ease (H1) and risk perception and behavior (H2). We test the H3 using Preacher and Hayes’ PROCESS model 8. We predict a mediation of distance x focus on risk perception and risk behavior by ease.

q23.value:
Relevant literature:
Rim, S., Hansen, J., & Trope, Y. (2013). What happens why? Psychological distance and focusing on causes versus consequences of events. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 104, 457-472.

attributes.title: The influence of temporal distance on the ease of assessing causes versus consequences of the coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) pandemia and its effect on risk perception and risk behavior
attributes.description: In this research we want to investigate whether temporal distance level influences the ease of assessing causes versus consequences of the Coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) pandemia. Additionally, we test whether this ease affects risk perception and risk behavior concerning the coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2).

attributes.title: Structural Determinants of Reaction to Covid  Pandemic and Compliance with Measures Aimed at Curbing the Pandemic
attributes.description: Governments and individual respond to the current pandemic in various ways. Understandably, different governments have different resources and approaches. In similar vein, political and social structure is different in countries. This project aims at investigating The how these important differences (Democractic structure, corruption perceptions, human development, life satisfaction, trust, social behaviour, suicide rates, Voting & civic involvement) influence compliance rates.

q1.value: Huseyin Cakal, Andreas Lieberoth, Giovanni A. Travaglino, Shiang-Yi Lin, Hyemin Han, Stavroula Chrona, Carlos C. Contreras, Cecilia Reyna

q2.value:
a) Political systems that rank lower on the democracy index will be able to contain the pandemic faster than those rank higher.
b) Higher social cohesion will be associated with higher levels of compliance.
c) Cultural diversity / ethnic fractionalization will be associated lower levels of compliance
more culturally diverse systems will respond slower and suffer more
d) State Fragility will be associated with lower compliance

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study will use observational data fromCOVIDiSTRESS global survey contains a number of variables (full survey at https://osf.io/z39us/ and already existing country level structural indices ( 1. Democracy index
2. Corruption perception index
3. Human development Index
4. OECD Social Cohesion Indicators (life satisfaction, Trust, social behaviour, Suicide rates, Voting & civic involvement)  
5. Fragile States Index )

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: This study is linked to COVIDiSTRESS global survey  (full survey at https://osf.io/z39us/

question.value: Participants will be recruited through individual collaborating researchers in participating countries. Participants will not receive any reimbursement.  Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q11.value: We are anticipating to have at least 50 participants from each participating country (currently 48 countries)

[Scale_PSS10] 	Perceived stress for the past week	Perceived Stress Scale (PSS-10).
10 items. 5-Point Likert Scale (1 =never, 5 = very often). Validated language versions where available. Back-translated where necessary. Mean score will be computed.	Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein (1983)
[OECD_insititutions]	Trust in country’s government and health system	6 questions: On a scale from 0-10 (0=not at all, 10=completely), how much you personally trust each of the institutions: (1) parliament/government?, (2) police, (3) civil service, (4) health system (added), (5) WHO (added), (6) government’s effort to handle
coronavirus (added). 	OECD guidelines on measuring institutional trust (OECD, 2017)

[Corona_concerns]	Concern over coronavirus	5 self-reported items to capture concerns about coronavirus consequences on a 6-Point Likert Scale (1=strongly disagree, 6=strongly agree): Concern about consequences of the coronavirus (1)...for yourself, (2)…for your family, (3)…for your close friends, (4)…for your country, (5)…for other countries across the globe. Mean score will be computed.	-
[Compliance]	Overall compliance with local prevention guidelines	The item “I have done everything I could possibly do as an individual, to reduce the spread of coronavirus”, out of 6 self-reported items to capture behaviors and reactions, including compliance with local prevention guidelines on a 6-Point Likert Scale (1=strongly disagree, 6=strongly agree). 	-

[generalised_trust]	Participants’ trust in most of people in the country of residence	10-point Likert scale from 1 (not at all) to 10 (completely)	
[country]	Country of residence	List of all countries where the survey is disseminated/spread.	
[SPS]	Available social provisions in critical/distressing situations	Social Provisions Scale short form SPS-10. 10 items. 6-Point Likert Scale (1 =strongly disagree, 6 = strongly agree). Validated language versions where available. Back-translated where necessary. Mean scores will be computed.	Steigen & Bergh (2019)

attributes.title: Conducta alimentaria durante el distanciamiento social en COVID19: protocolo de un estudio transversal
attributes.description: Ante la falta de información existente sobre las conductas alimentarias en el distanciamiento social actual debido al COVID19, se realiza esta investigación para abordar este vacío de conocimiento.

q1.value: Eduard Baladia, Rafael Almendra-Pegueros, Catalina Ramírez-Contreras, Pía Rojas-Cárdenas, Anna Vila-Martí, José Moya Osorio, Evelia Apolinar-Jiménez, Alberto Lazzara-López, Kristian Buhring-Bonacich, María Celeste Nessier, Sophia Eugenia Martínez-Vázquez, Saby Camacho-Lopez, Angela Zambrana Vera, Patricia Martínez López, Eva María Navarrete-Muñoz

q2.value:
Primario: Identificar las conductas alimentarias a través de la restricción cognitiva, alimentación emocional  e ingesta incontrolada y explorar los factores asociados con estas conductas en adultos durante la pandemia del COVID-19 en países hispanoamericanos.

Secundarios: 
●	Explorar si hay diferencias en las conductas alimentarias según el número de días de confinamiento. 
●	Explorar si hay diferencias en las conductas alimentarias según sexo, edad o nivel educativo o país de procedencia.
●	Explorar si existe asociación en las conductas alimentarias con el diagnóstico previo de una enfermedad crónica no transmisible, o con las medidas antropométricas básicas.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Estudio observacional de corte transversal

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Se estableció como universo de referencia:
●	Población general de entre 18 y 65 años de ambos sexos 
●	De cualquier país hispanoamericanos 
●	En situación de distanciamiento social / cuarentena / auto-aislamiento de la pandemia del COVID19 de al menos 7 días 

Se realizará un muestreo no probabilístico por conveniencia, aceptándose todos los participantes alcanzados a través de diferentes estrategias de captación.

Instrumento: cuestionario (ad hoc) online que será difundido por redes sociales y correos electrónicos. Incluirá el Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire-R18 (TFEQ-SP).

q11.value: No se establece tamaño muestral a priori. Se calculará el poder en función de la muestra alcanzada.

question.value:
Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire-R18 (TFEQ-SP): El cuestionario mide tres aspectos diferentes del comportamiento alimentario: (a) alimentación restringida (definida como restricción consciente de la ingesta de alimentos dirigida a controlar el peso corporal y/o promover la pérdida de peso); (b) comer sin control (la tendencia a comer más de lo habitual debido a una pérdida de control sobre la ingesta con una sensación subjetiva de hambre); y (c) alimentación emocional (incapacidad para resistir las señales emocionales, comer como respuesta a diferentes emociones negativas). El cuestionario consta de 18 ítems que se miden en una escala de respuesta de 4 puntos (definitivamente cierto: 1, mayormente verdadero: 2, mayormente falso: 3, definitivamente falso: 4) y los puntajes de los ítems se suman en puntajes de subescala: restricción cognitiva (RC), alimentación emocional (EE) e ingesta incontrolada (UE) (11).

Datos antropométricos básicos: peso (kg; auto-reportado), altura (m; autoreportada), IMC (estimada), circunferencia abdominal (cm; auto-reportada). 

Datos de estado de salud: diagnóstico previo de enfermedades crónicas: diabetes, hipertensión, cáncer, obesidad, y tiempo con esos padecimientos ya diagnosticados.

Datos sobre el distanciamiento social/cuarentena/aislamiento: días de distanciamiento social que lleva el individuo, tipo de convivencia (sólo/a, en familia sin hijos, en familia con hijos), veces que salió de casa y finalidad. En el anexo XX se incluyen las fechas oficiales de inicio de confinamiento.

Datos sociodemográficos básicos: en qué país resides de hispanoamérica (incluir un listado de países), sexo (mujer/hombre), edad, nivel educativo (primarios, secundarios, universitarios), distinción de profesional sanitario, situación laboral previa a la pandemia y actual (trabaja, teletrabaja, jubilado pensionista, parado /cobrando subsidio, parado /sin cobrar, estudiante, trabajo doméstico no remunerado, u otras situaciones), estado civil,  cuantas personas viven en su casa normalmente, ingresos promedio familiares.  

Datos relacionados con estilo de vida antes de la pandemia y actualmente: calidad del sueño, actividad física, uso de pantallas, hábito tabáquico (nunca fumador; ex-fumador; fumador)

Datos relacionados con la compra de alimentos: veces has salido a hacer la compra en la última semana, cuánto dinero aproximado gastate en la última compra de comida que realizaste, comida a domicilio.

Todos los análisis se realizará utilizando el software estadístico libre R y se establecerá contrastes bilaterales y con un nivel de significación 0,05. 

Se realizará un análisis descriptivo univariante utilizando n y % para variables cualitativas. Se comprobará la normalidad de las variables cuantitativas usando el test de Kolmogorov-Smirnov, en aquellas que sigan una distribución normal se usará media y desviación típica y en las que no sigan esa distribución normal se usará mediana y rango intercuartílico. 

Para los análisis bivariantes entre las tres variables de conducta alimentaria según las variables sociodemográficas y de estilos de vida se utilizaran la media o la mediana así como la desviación típica y el rango intercuartílico para describir las conductas según sigan una distribución normal o no. Para calcular el p-valor de comparación se utilizará el test t-Student o ANOVA si siguen una distribución normal o U de Mann-Whitney o Kruskall Wallis si no sigue una distribución normal dependiendo del número categorías de las variables sociodemográficas y/o de estilos de vida.

Para explorar los factores asociados a una mayor puntuación en las variables de conducta alimentaria se utiliza modelos de regresión lineal multivariantes clásicos o robustos por el método de mínimos cuadrados dependiendo si se cumplen o no las hipótesis del modelo de regresión. 

Posibles sesgos

Sesgo de voluntariado (sesgo de selección): participación de voluntarios o efecto de autoselección que conduzca a un sesgo de selección, siendo incluidos personas sistemáticamente diferentes a la población general.

Sesgo de autoreporte (sesgo de información): error sistemático al proveer los datos antropométricos y sociodemográficos de forma autoadministrada. Se espera que se distribuya de igual forma en toda la población, y por tanto el sesgo será de información no diferencia y por lo tanto se subestimaran las asociaciones.

Sesgo de desgaste: sujetos que acepten hacer la encuesta, pero que no la completan, que será desconocido o no en función del software utilizado.

q23.value:
Aspectos Éticos y consentimiento informado.

El presente trabajo se apega a los lineamientos éticos en investigación en seres humanos, establecidos en la Declaración de Helsinki de 1964 y sus posteriores enmiendas, incluida la 64ª. Asamblea General de la Asociación Médica Mundial de Fortaleza, Brasil en 2013 (Asociación Médica Mundial. Declaración de Helsinki de la AMM-Principios Éticos para las Investigaciones Médicas en Seres Humanos [sede web]. Finlandia: Asociación Médica Mundial; junio 1967. URL disponible en: https://www.wma.net/es/policies-post/declaracion-de-helsinki-de-la-amm-principios-eticos-para- las-investigaciones-medicas-en-seres-humanos/  ), así como con las elaboradas por el Consejo de Oragnizaciones Internacionales de Ciencias Médicas (CIOMS, por sus siglas en inglés) en colaboración con la OMS (Organización Panamericana de la Salud y Consejo de Organizaciones Internacionales de las Ciencias Médica. Pautas éticas internacionales para la investigación relacionada con la salud con seres humanos, Cuarta Edición. Ginebra: Consejo de Organizaciones Internacionales de las Ciencias Médicas (CIOMS); 2016). Se trata de un estudio observacional y transversal, que implica un riesgo bajo para los participantes, toda vez que no se hará intervención alguna. Si bien los datos se obtendrán a partir de cuestionarios realizados mediante dispositivos electrónicos y a través de internet, los investigadores se comprometen a establecer los mecanismos necesarios para salvaguardar los datos personales de cada participante, toda vez que no se recabará información sensible que puedan identificarles. Además, atendiendo al principio de autonomía, se recabará, también vía online, el consentimiento previa información.

attributes.title: RNA-Seq analysis of early transcriptional responses to activation in the leukaemic Jurkat E6.1 T cell line

summary.value:
Outputs from RNA-seq data analysis of Jurkat E6.1 cells. Files as follows:

Dataset S1 – Raw count values for all samples.

Dataset S2 – Full list of differentially expressed genes between resting and 2 h stimulated (no chemokine) conditions.

Dataset S3 – Full list of GO terms significantly associated with differentially expressed genes between resting and 2 h stimulated (no chemokine) conditions.
