attributes.title: Attitudes towards the rehabilitation and punishment of young offenders
attributes.description: This study builds upon previous research exploring the influence of perpetrator characteristics on perceptions of guilt and responsibility for a criminal act. This literature lacks in exploring the impact of social background, and thus this study aims to investigate this potential effect through manipulating how a perpetrator is described, either being a looked-after child or not. Furthermore, this study aims to investigate the role of occupation due to research highlighting this as an important factor in influencing attitudes towards offenders (Willis, Levenson, & Ward, 2010). For example, discrepancies have been found in the attitudes of community members and professionals who work closely with offenders (Pickett, Mancini, Mears, & Gertz, 2014). This has an impact on rehabilitative outcomes, as Willis et al. (2010) argue desistance from re-offending to be more difficult when professionals hold negative attitudes towards an offender.

q2.value:
All hypotheses are directional.

1.	Participants will rate the individual described as a looked-after child more negatively on emotion-rating scales (more anger and less pity towards them) and will evoke more negative stereotypes (more aggressive, less competent, less warm). 
The justification for this hypothesis comes from research by Clow and Leach (2015). Within this, it is evidenced that offenders face pervasive stigma within society often characterised by negative stereotypes that convey an image of danger of threat. Thus, when an individual occupies a low-status position in society, they may also be subject to different forms of prejudice (contemptuous or paternalistic; Fiske et al., 2002). Paternalistic prejudice is related to the concept of pity, characterised by feelings of warmth, whereas contemptuous prejudice is related to anger. Due to the lack of research on prejudice towards looked-after children, it will be explored whether contemptuous or paternalistic prejudice best describes participant responses towards this group. Due to the assumption that looked-after children occupy a more low-status position in society than individuals raised within a family setting, it is hypothesised that participants would associate more negative stereotypes with this group as a result of greater social stigma (less warmth and competence; Scott, Reppucci, Atonishak, & DeGennaro, 2006). 

2.	The individual described as a looked-after child will be deemed more responsible for the described crime and will be judged to be less capable of rehabilitation.
This hypothesis is based within research by Garrett (1999) which highlighted how perceptions of looked-after children as ‘troublesome’ are pervasive in the existing literature. Therefore, it was hypothesised that a suspect described as raised in care would be deemed more responsible for a crime and less capable of rehabilitation. Further to this, Scott et al. (2006) argue that young offenders are increasingly subject to punitive action in the justice system as a result of negative public opinion. Despite this widespread concern, Scott et al. (2006) evidenced how negative public attitudes are often targeted to particular groups within society, being influenced by factors such as race and appearance (how physically mature an individual looks). Thus, it is hypothesised that looked-after children will similarly face more punitive attitudes than an individual raised within a family setting, being judged to be more responsible and less capable of rehabilitation. 

3.	Participants will report being less comfortable with measures of social distance for the looked-after child. 
This hypothesis is based within research by Clow and Leach (2015) which indicated the need for more research investigating how public perception influences potential behaviour, as opposed to what the public believes the government should be doing. Thus, it is deemed important to explore how physically and psychologically close participants are willing to become to looked-after children. This can be measured by asking questions about how likely it is a participant would rent a house or live on the same street as someone described as a looked-after child (Howard, 2019). Research has indicated that participants (including community corrections officers) who reported desiring greater social distance from an offender were significantly less likely to believe that offenders are inherently good people who are capable of rehabilitation (Helfgott & Gunnison, 2008). Thus, social distance measures are deemed to be an effective way to gauge public opinion towards traditionally stigmatised groups. This is linked to the concept of discrimination in that individuals deemed to hold a lower position in society are more likely to receive negative judgement on social distance measures. Therefore, due to research suggesting that looked-after children are often characterised as ‘troublesome’, it is hypothesised that participants would be less comfortable with measures of social distance (Garrett, 1999). 

4.	Participant occupation: Those with experience working within the criminal justice sector will be less likely to assign responsibility to a youth offender than those without, and will believe more so in the potential for rehabilitation.
Willis, Levenson, and Ward (2010) argued for the importance of research investigating the attitudes of professionals who work closely with offenders. This impacts upon rehabilitative outcomes in that professionals who hold negative attitudes towards offenders are deemed more likely to adopt punitive and confrontational styles in their interactions (Willis et al., 2010). In accordance with this, it was found that displays of empathy and warmth facilitated treatment change and therefore it has been argued that effective rehabilitation partially hinges on the way offenders are regarded by both the public and professionals (Willis et al., 2010). Subsequent to this, it was theorised that having greater contact with offenders would result in more positive attitude ratings towards them, evidencing why students and general community members are generally seen to endorse more negative attitudes than those working with offenders. As a result, it is hypothesised that those with experience working in the criminal justice sector would be less likely to assign responsibility to a youth offender than those without, and would believe more so in the potential for rehabilitation.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a 2x2 between-subjects design comprising 2 factors with 2 levels. 
The two factors in this study are upbringing condition (whether a fictitious perpetrator is described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting) and participant occupation (whether participants have experience working in the criminal justice system or not).

q7.value:
Simple randomisation will be used to assign participants to one of two vignette conditions. 
The vignettes will be displayed in the form of a newspaper article describing a fictional crime. Within this, an adolescent perpetrator is described as either raised in the care system or within a family setting. 
These will be identical in structure, both displaying the same basic details of the crime before going onto more specific details of the suspect. Within this, details of the suspect’s upbringing will be manipulated. For example, the ‘looked-after’ perpetrator will be described as ‘raised in foster care’, whereas the other vignette describes the perpetrator as ‘from a middle-class upbringing’. Furthermore, the vignette will either describe the perpetrator’s ‘foster carer’ or ‘mother’ being ‘not present’ or ‘present’ at the time of arrest, respectively. 
Randomization of the vignette conditions will be done via Qualtrics which is the online survey platform being used for the study. Both vignette blocks were added into a randomizer function within the survey flow, which will randomly and evenly present 1 of the vignettes to participants.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be obtained from the general population and will be voluntarily sampled through the use of two main methods:
1. Social media: Advertisements will be placed on Facebook for voluntary participation within the research study. This allows for snowballing methods of recruitment that can be used to target potential adult participants who meet the inclusion criteria (aged 18 or over). 
2. Purposive sampling will be used to identify participants based upon pre-arranged selection criteria that state half of the participant sample should have experience working within the criminal justice sector. This is an effective method of sampling in this case due to this being a variable of interest in investigating the potential influence of occupation. Therefore, sampling participants based upon certain characteristics, knowledge and experience is necessary (Etikan, Musa, & Alkassim, 2016). The decision to use individuals working within the criminal justice system is due to a lack of research being available on this group, with most research regarding opinions towards young offenders being gauged from the general public which inherently fails to gather information from those that work most closely with this group (Willis, Levenson, & Ward, 2010). The criminal justice worker sample will be recruited through speculative applications to police stations within the United Kingdom, within which the lead researcher has some existing contact from previous volunteering work.
No payment will be offered to participants in return for completion of the study. 
The inclusion and exclusion criteria for this study state that participants cannot take part if they are under the age of 18 and not a resident of the United Kingdom. This will be reinforced through the consent and information sheet given to participants. 
The study timeline is that data collection is expected to begin in April 2020 before closing in July in order to be analysed before the project deadline on August 7th 2020.

q11.value: The target sample size is 126 participants.

q12.value: An a priori G*Power analysis was conducted. This indicated a target sample size of 126 for a medium effect size of .25, .80 power and .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
The condition will be manipulated for participants through the use of 2 vignettes which present a hypothetical crime in the form of a newspaper article. Within this, an adolescent perpetrator will be described as either raised in care or within a family setting. 
The 2 vignettes will be identical except for information describing the perpetrator, in which details regarding their upbringing will be manipulated. For example, the ‘looked-after’ perpetrator will be described as ‘raised in foster care’, whereas the other vignette describes the perpetrator as ‘from a middle-class upbringing’. Furthermore, the vignette will either describe the perpetrator’s ‘foster carer’ or ‘mother’ being ‘not present’ or ‘present’ at the time of arrest, respectively. 
The perpetrator described in both of the vignettes will be male. This decision was made due to the fact that a large amount of research exploring public attitudes towards offenders has used male perpetrators within stimulus materials (Scott et al., 2006; Howard, 2019). Furthermore, an increasing focus on female perpetration in recent years has highlighted this group to display unique and distinct patterns of criminality (Bloom & Covington, 2001). Thus, the use of a female perpetrator within the vignette in the current study would potentially mean that results aren’t able to be effectively compared with past research on public opinion. Furthermore, due to research suggesting that female offenders may be deemed more ‘vulnerable’, it is evident that public opinion toward them would differ from that of a male (Zager, 2018). Thus, the aspect of female offending wasn’t included in the present study and may instead be a viable route for future research.

1.	Demographic: Participants will complete 3 questions regarding their sex (male, female, other, rather not say), age in years and whether they have worked within the criminal justice sector.
2.	Emotion-rating: This scale was adapted from that used by Clow and Leach (2015). This examines contemptuous and paternalistic prejudice by asking participants to indicate levels of anger, pity, fear and surprise towards the perpetrator. This will be rated from 1-5, with 5 indicating more extreme scores.  
3.	Stereotypes: This assesses dispositional assumptions about the perpetrator, being clustered in 3 main categories (aggression, competence, warmth) according to Clow and Leach (2015) and the stereotype content model (Fiske et al., 2002). This will be assessed on a 1-5 scale, with 5 indicating more extreme scores. There will also be space provided if participants want to elaborate on their answers. 
4.	Responsibility: This measure was adapted from Scott et al. (2006). This assesses perceptions of the perpetrator’s maturity, such as how much they were able to appreciate the consequences of the crime, as well as how responsible they are. This will be rated on a 1-5 scale with 5 indicating more extreme scores. Space will also be provided for written elaboration. 
5.	Rehabilitation and discrimination: Participants will be asked to indicate their agreement with statements about the perpetrator’s potential for rehabilitation on a 1-5 scale (very unlikely- very likely). This will be followed by a forced-choice question regarding if participants would be more willing to support punitive or rehabilitative sentencing for the perpetrator. Finally, this measure will include questions regarding if participants believe the perpetrator is entitled to forms of government assistance. This was adapted from measures used by Clow and Leach (2015). 
6.	Social-distance: This measure was adapted from Triandis and Triandis (1960). This explores how psychologically close participants are willing to become to members of another group. This will ask participants to indicate their opinion to a number of real-life scenarios (e.g. how likely would you be to rent housing to the perpetrator?) on a 1-5 (very unlikely-very likely) scale. Space will also be provided for written elaboration. 
7.	General attitudes: This measure was adapted from that used by Scott et al. (2006) to assesses participants’ attitudes towards youth crime, rehabilitation and punishment independently of the vignette. This will ask participants to indicate levels of agreement with statements such as ‘Juvenile courts treat adolescents too leniently’ on a 1-5 scale. Questions will also be included that ask participants for their opinion of looked-after children more generally, as well as how much they feel the media influences their opinions. Space will also be provided for written elaboration.

Some of the measures described above will include averaging scores into a single variable for analysis. 
The stereotypes measure will be averaged into 3 variables (aggression, competency and warmth). Aggression will comprise ‘how aggressive would you assume [the perpetrator is]?’ and ‘how violent would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’. Competency will comprise ‘how intelligent would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’, ‘how impulsive would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’ (reverse scored) and ‘how likely would you be to assume [the perpetrator] is suffering from a mental illness?’ (reverse scored). Warmth will comprise ‘how cold or warm would you assume [the perpetrator] is as a person?’, ‘how friendly would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’, ‘how respected would you assume [the perpetrator] is within the local community?’ and ‘how trustworthy would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’. These are all tested on a Likert scale from 1-5. 

The responsibility measure will comprise 4 questions: ‘how much would you say [the perpetrator] was able to appreciate the consequences of his actions?’, ‘How much would you say [the perpetrator] was able to appreciate the impact of his crime on others?’, ‘How much responsibility would you assign the perpetrator for the crime committed?’ and ‘How likely would you be to argue that [the perpetrator’s] actions were a result of peer influence?’ (reverse scored). These are all tested on a Likert scale from 1-5.

Potential for rehabilitation will be assessed by combining 4 questions into an overall variable: ‘How likely do you think it is that [the perpetrator] will change or outgrow his delinquent behaviour?’, ‘How likely would you say it is that [the perpetrator] could lead a productive life?’, ‘How likely would you say it is that [the perpetrator] could be rehabilitated?’ and ‘how likely is it that [the perpetrator] would commit a future offence?’ (reverse scored). These are all tested on a Likert scale from 1-5. 

Finally, to assess social distance 5 questions will be combined into an overall social distance score. The 5 questions are: ‘How likely would you be to rent housing to [the perpetrator]?’, ‘How likely would you be to employ [the perpetrator]?’, ‘How comfortable would you be living in the same town as [the perpetrator]?’, ‘How comfortable would you be living on the same street as [the perpetrator]?’, ‘How comfortable would you be if a family member married [the perpetrator]?’. These are all tested on a Likert scale from 1-5. 

In order to do this, a new variable will be computed in each of these cases that represents the sum/total score for each participant on the items that are measured within that subscale. As mentioned above, items that measure something counter-indicative will be reverse coded to make low scores high and vice versa. In order to compute scale scores a syntax code will be used within SPSS. For example, the syntax to create a sum score for the ‘aggression’ subscale will be: COMPUTE S_aggression = SUM(aggressive, violent).

Demographics: 
Participant demographics will be examined by running a descriptive statistics procedure on SPSS. 
Age will be entered as a numerical digit, due to the questionnaire asking participants to enter their age in years (e.g. 30). 
Gender will be coded as: Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4.
Occupation is a dichotomous question asking participants if they have ever worked within the criminal justice system. This will be coded as: Yes = 1, No = 2.
This procedure will be run by utilising the descriptive statistics procedure, producing N, minimum, maximum, mean, and standard deviation for these measures. 

For all multiple regression analyses, preliminary tests will be conducted to ensure data meet assumptions.

Emotion-rating scales: 
This emotion-rating scale will be used to assess emotions towards the perpetrator described in the vignette. 
There are 5 questions in this measure. The 2 questions that will be analysed are those that ask participants how much pity and anger they feel towards the perpetrator, the other 3 questions are filler questions that won’t be included in the analysis. Anger is hypothesised to represent contemptuous prejudice and pity is hypothesised to represent paternalistic prejudice (Clow and Leach, 2015). 
A hierarchical multiple regression will be conducted in order to analyse this data. 
The dependent variable will be ratings of anger and ratings of pity. 
The independent variables will be upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4). The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 1). 
The reasoning for using a multiple regression here is based on the ability to explore how a set of variables is able to predict the outcome as a whole as well as the relative contribution of each variable. Demographic variables such as participant age and gender are included due to multiple regression allowing such variables to be statistically controlled for within the model. Each independent variable will be assessed on what it adds to the prediction of the outcome variable.
As per hypothesis 1, it is expected that participants will rate the individual described as a looked-after child more negatively on emotion-rating scales (more anger and less pity towards them).

Stereotypes: 
This measure is split into 3 sub-tests measuring aggression, competency and warmth.
A hierarchical multiple regression will be conducted to assess the influence of a set of independent variables on perceptions of warmth, competency, and aggression.
The dependent variable here will be sum scores of warmth, competency, and aggression.
Independent variables will be upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4). 
The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 1). 
As per hypothesis 1, it is expected that participants will view the looked-after child as less warm, less competent and more aggressive.

Responsibility: 
The 4 questions in this measure will be averaged for an overall responsibility score. 
A hierarchal multiple regression will be conducted to assess the influence of a set of independent variables on judgements of overall responsibility (the dependent variable). The independent variables will be upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4). 
The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing and participant occupation will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 2 and 4). 
As per hypothesis 2, it is expected the individual described as a looked-after child will be deemed more responsible for the described crime. As predicted in hypothesis 4, it is also expected that participants with experience working in the criminal justice system will deem the perpetrator as less responsible.

Rehabilitation and discrimination: 
Potential for rehabilitation is measured by 4 questions (1. how likely is the perpetrator to outgrow their behaviour, 2. how likely is it the perpetrator will lead a productive life, 3. how likely is the perpetrator to be rehabilitated, 4. how likely is the perpetrator to commit a future offence). This will be averaged into a single index in which high scores indicate a high potential for rehabilitation (question 4 will be reverse scored). This will be the dependent variable.
This will then be assessed using a hierarchical multiple regression to explore the influence of upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4).
The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing and participant occupation will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 2 and 4). 
As per hypothesis 2, it is expected that the individual described as a looked-after child will be deemed less capable of rehabilitation. Furthermore, as per hypothesis 4, it is also expected participants with experience working in the criminal justice system will believe more so in the potential for rehabilitation.

Participant’s choice of sentence for the perpetrator in the vignette will then be predicted from the type of upbringing that is described and the participant’s occupation. This will be done using a forward stepwise logistic regression (binary logistic function in SPSS). The research question here would thus be to explore what factors predict the likelihood that respondents would assign rehabilitative/ punitive sentencing. 
The dependent variable here will be the question, ‘Would you be more likely to support punitive or rehabilitative measures for [the perpetrator]?’, in which participants have a binary response of ‘punitive’ or ‘rehabilitative’. 
The two independent variables will be perpetrator upbringing (looked-after child = 1, family raised = 2) and participant occupation (criminal justice experience = 1, no criminal justice experience = 2). 
As per hypothesis 2, it is expected that the perpetrator described as a looked-after child will be more likely to receive punitive action. Furthermore, as per hypothesis 4, it is expected that participants with experience working in the criminal justice system will be less likely to assign punitive measures to both groups. 

Social distance:
Social distance is measured by 5 questions which will be combined into an overall social distance score (higher scores indicate participants being more comfortable to the perpetrator). 
A hierarchical multiple regression will be conducted to assess the influence of a range of independent variables on the outcome variable (overall social distance score). 
The independent variables here will include upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4). 
The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 3). 
As per hypothesis 3, it is expected that participants will report being less comfortable with measures of social distance for the looked-after child.

q19.value: A p<.05 criteria will be used for all statistical analyses.

q20.value:
Due to certain analyses (e.g. multiple regression) being sensitive to the influence of outliers, this will be examined in order to not reduce the validity of results. 
In order to assess for outliers within logistic and multiple regression analyses, I will ask SPSS to indicate outliers that lie outside 3 standard deviations. The output will display any outliers identified, from which point it will be determined if these represent a procedural outlier (error in data entry or failure of participant procedure following). If this is the case, the outliers will be removed via the data editor window in SPSS. If this is not the case and outliers represent genuine data, analyses will be reported with the outliers included in order to represent the full range of opinion. Analyses will also be run excluding extreme cases to see how this influences the results.

q21.value:
In order to inspect the data for missing cases, ‘descriptives’ will be run on SPSS in order to find which percentage of values is missing for each of the variables. 
If more than 5% of responses are missing, missing case variables will be created and correlations will be run to see if these are correlated with any of the other variables. 
Cases will subsequently by excluded pairwise (analysis by analysis), in which participants are only excluded if they are missing the data for the specific analysis being performed.

q22.value:
Perpetrator mental health will be analysed, exploring if an individual described as a looked-after child will be deemed more or less mentally ill than someone raised in a family setting. This will be assessed through the use of 2 questions, one of which being ‘how likely would you be to assume [the perpetrator] is suffering from a mental illness?’. To analyse this, a hierarchical multiple regression will be conducted to assess the influence of perpetrator upbringing on judgements of mental illness. Other independent variables will include participant occupation, age and gender. 
The second question asks participants to choose which mental illness they would assume the perpetrator is suffering from (depression, anxiety, PTSD, schizophrenia, conduct disorder, none of the above, I don’t know). In order to analyse this data ‘descriptives’ will be run to obtain the frequency and percentage of participants who chose each answer. 

Finally, general attitudes towards looked-after children will be assessed through the questions ‘how comfortable would you be living near children raised in the care system’ and ‘how troublesome would you assume looked-after children to be?’. These will be assessed via a hierarchical multiple regression, with the independent variables being participant occupation, age, and gender in order to explore if these variables influence attitudes towards looked-after children.

In accordance with this, it was found that displays of empathy and warmth facilitated treatment change and therefore it has been argued that effective rehabilitation partially hinges on the way offenders are regarded by both the public and professionals (Willis et al., 2010). Subsequent to this, it was theorised that having greater contact with offenders would result in more positive attitude ratings towards them, evidencing why students and general community members are generally seen to endorse more negative attitudes than those working with offenders. As a result, it is hypothesised that those with experience working in the criminal justice sector would be less likely to assign responsibility to a youth offender than those without, and would believe more so in the potential for rehabilitation.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7:
Simple randomisation will be used to assign participants to one of two vignette conditions. 
The vignettes will be displayed in the form of a newspaper article describing a fictional crime. Within this, an adolescent perpetrator is described as either raised in the care system or within a family setting. 
These will be identical in structure, both displaying the same basic details of the crime before going onto more specific details of the suspect. Within this, details of the suspect’s upbringing will be manipulated. For example, the ‘looked-after’ perpetrator will be described as ‘raised in foster care’, whereas the other vignette describes the perpetrator as ‘from a middle-class upbringing’. Furthermore, the vignette will either describe the perpetrator’s ‘foster carer’ or ‘mother’ being ‘not present’ or ‘present’ at the time of arrest, respectively. 
Randomization of the vignette conditions will be done via Qualtrics which is the online survey platform being used for the study. Both vignette blocks were added into a randomizer function within the survey flow, which will randomly and evenly present 1 of the vignettes to participants.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: The target sample size is 126 participants.
registration_responses.q12: An a priori G*Power analysis was conducted. This indicated a target sample size of 126 for a medium effect size of .25, .80 power and .05 alpha error probability.
registration_responses.q19: A p<.05 criteria will be used for all statistical analyses.
registration_responses.q20:
Due to certain analyses (e.g. multiple regression) being sensitive to the influence of outliers, this will be examined in order to not reduce the validity of results. 
In order to assess for outliers within logistic and multiple regression analyses, I will ask SPSS to indicate outliers that lie outside 3 standard deviations. The output will display any outliers identified, from which point it will be determined if these represent a procedural outlier (error in data entry or failure of participant procedure following). If this is the case, the outliers will be removed via the data editor window in SPSS. If this is not the case and outliers represent genuine data, analyses will be reported with the outliers included in order to represent the full range of opinion. Analyses will also be run excluding extreme cases to see how this influences the results.
registration_responses.q21:
In order to inspect the data for missing cases, ‘descriptives’ will be run on SPSS in order to find which percentage of values is missing for each of the variables. 
If more than 5% of responses are missing, missing case variables will be created and correlations will be run to see if these are correlated with any of the other variables. 
Cases will subsequently by excluded pairwise (analysis by analysis), in which participants are only excluded if they are missing the data for the specific analysis being performed.
registration_responses.q22:
Perpetrator mental health will be analysed, exploring if an individual described as a looked-after child will be deemed more or less mentally ill than someone raised in a family setting. This will be assessed through the use of 2 questions, one of which being ‘how likely would you be to assume [the perpetrator] is suffering from a mental illness?’. To analyse this, a hierarchical multiple regression will be conducted to assess the influence of perpetrator upbringing on judgements of mental illness. Other independent variables will include participant occupation, age and gender. 
The second question asks participants to choose which mental illness they would assume the perpetrator is suffering from (depression, anxiety, PTSD, schizophrenia, conduct disorder, none of the above, I don’t know). In order to analyse this data ‘descriptives’ will be run to obtain the frequency and percentage of participants who chose each answer. 

Finally, general attitudes towards looked-after children will be assessed through the questions ‘how comfortable would you be living near children raised in the care system’ and ‘how troublesome would you assume looked-after children to be?’. These will be assessed via a hierarchical multiple regression, with the independent variables being participant occupation, age, and gender in order to explore if these variables influence attitudes towards looked-after children.
registration_responses.q6.question:
This is a 2x2 between-subjects design comprising 2 factors with 2 levels. 
The two factors in this study are upbringing condition (whether a fictitious perpetrator is described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting) and participant occupation (whether participants have experience working in the criminal justice system or not).
registration_responses.q10.question:
Participants will be obtained from the general population and will be voluntarily sampled through the use of two main methods:
1. Social media: Advertisements will be placed on Facebook for voluntary participation within the research study. This allows for snowballing methods of recruitment that can be used to target potential adult participants who meet the inclusion criteria (aged 18 or over). 
2. Purposive sampling will be used to identify participants based upon pre-arranged selection criteria that state half of the participant sample should have experience working within the criminal justice sector. This is an effective method of sampling in this case due to this being a variable of interest in investigating the potential influence of occupation. Therefore, sampling participants based upon certain characteristics, knowledge and experience is necessary (Etikan, Musa, & Alkassim, 2016). The decision to use individuals working within the criminal justice system is due to a lack of research being available on this group, with most research regarding opinions towards young offenders being gauged from the general public which inherently fails to gather information from those that work most closely with this group (Willis, Levenson, & Ward, 2010). The criminal justice worker sample will be recruited through speculative applications to police stations within the United Kingdom, within which the lead researcher has some existing contact from previous volunteering work.
No payment will be offered to participants in return for completion of the study. 
The inclusion and exclusion criteria for this study state that participants cannot take part if they are under the age of 18 and not a resident of the United Kingdom. This will be reinforced through the consent and information sheet given to participants. 
The study timeline is that data collection is expected to begin in April 2020 before closing in July in order to be analysed before the project deadline on August 7th 2020.
registration_responses.q14.question:
The condition will be manipulated for participants through the use of 2 vignettes which present a hypothetical crime in the form of a newspaper article. Within this, an adolescent perpetrator will be described as either raised in care or within a family setting. 
The 2 vignettes will be identical except for information describing the perpetrator, in which details regarding their upbringing will be manipulated. For example, the ‘looked-after’ perpetrator will be described as ‘raised in foster care’, whereas the other vignette describes the perpetrator as ‘from a middle-class upbringing’. Furthermore, the vignette will either describe the perpetrator’s ‘foster carer’ or ‘mother’ being ‘not present’ or ‘present’ at the time of arrest, respectively. 
The perpetrator described in both of the vignettes will be male. This decision was made due to the fact that a large amount of research exploring public attitudes towards offenders has used male perpetrators within stimulus materials (Scott et al., 2006; Howard, 2019). Furthermore, an increasing focus on female perpetration in recent years has highlighted this group to display unique and distinct patterns of criminality (Bloom & Covington, 2001). Thus, the use of a female perpetrator within the vignette in the current study would potentially mean that results aren’t able to be effectively compared with past research on public opinion. Furthermore, due to research suggesting that female offenders may be deemed more ‘vulnerable’, it is evident that public opinion toward them would differ from that of a male (Zager, 2018). Thus, the aspect of female offending wasn’t included in the present study and may instead be a viable route for future research.
registration_responses.q15.question:
1.	Demographic: Participants will complete 3 questions regarding their sex (male, female, other, rather not say), age in years and whether they have worked within the criminal justice sector.
2.	Emotion-rating: This scale was adapted from that used by Clow and Leach (2015). This examines contemptuous and paternalistic prejudice by asking participants to indicate levels of anger, pity, fear and surprise towards the perpetrator. This will be rated from 1-5, with 5 indicating more extreme scores.  
3.	Stereotypes: This assesses dispositional assumptions about the perpetrator, being clustered in 3 main categories (aggression, competence, warmth) according to Clow and Leach (2015) and the stereotype content model (Fiske et al., 2002). This will be assessed on a 1-5 scale, with 5 indicating more extreme scores. There will also be space provided if participants want to elaborate on their answers. 
4.	Responsibility: This measure was adapted from Scott et al. (2006). This assesses perceptions of the perpetrator’s maturity, such as how much they were able to appreciate the consequences of the crime, as well as how responsible they are. This will be rated on a 1-5 scale with 5 indicating more extreme scores. Space will also be provided for written elaboration. 
5.	Rehabilitation and discrimination: Participants will be asked to indicate their agreement with statements about the perpetrator’s potential for rehabilitation on a 1-5 scale (very unlikely- very likely). This will be followed by a forced-choice question regarding if participants would be more willing to support punitive or rehabilitative sentencing for the perpetrator. Finally, this measure will include questions regarding if participants believe the perpetrator is entitled to forms of government assistance. This was adapted from measures used by Clow and Leach (2015). 
6.	Social-distance: This measure was adapted from Triandis and Triandis (1960). This explores how psychologically close participants are willing to become to members of another group. This will ask participants to indicate their opinion to a number of real-life scenarios (e.g. how likely would you be to rent housing to the perpetrator?) on a 1-5 (very unlikely-very likely) scale. Space will also be provided for written elaboration. 
7.	General attitudes: This measure was adapted from that used by Scott et al. (2006) to assesses participants’ attitudes towards youth crime, rehabilitation and punishment independently of the vignette. This will ask participants to indicate levels of agreement with statements such as ‘Juvenile courts treat adolescents too leniently’ on a 1-5 scale. Questions will also be included that ask participants for their opinion of looked-after children more generally, as well as how much they feel the media influences their opinions. Space will also be provided for written elaboration.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Some of the measures described above will include averaging scores into a single variable for analysis. 
The stereotypes measure will be averaged into 3 variables (aggression, competency and warmth). Aggression will comprise ‘how aggressive would you assume [the perpetrator is]?’ and ‘how violent would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’. Competency will comprise ‘how intelligent would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’, ‘how impulsive would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’ (reverse scored) and ‘how likely would you be to assume [the perpetrator] is suffering from a mental illness?’ (reverse scored). Warmth will comprise ‘how cold or warm would you assume [the perpetrator] is as a person?’, ‘how friendly would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’, ‘how respected would you assume [the perpetrator] is within the local community?’ and ‘how trustworthy would you assume [the perpetrator] is?’. These are all tested on a Likert scale from 1-5. 

The responsibility measure will comprise 4 questions: ‘how much would you say [the perpetrator] was able to appreciate the consequences of his actions?’, ‘How much would you say [the perpetrator] was able to appreciate the impact of his crime on others?’, ‘How much responsibility would you assign the perpetrator for the crime committed?’ and ‘How likely would you be to argue that [the perpetrator’s] actions were a result of peer influence?’ (reverse scored). These are all tested on a Likert scale from 1-5.

Potential for rehabilitation will be assessed by combining 4 questions into an overall variable: ‘How likely do you think it is that [the perpetrator] will change or outgrow his delinquent behaviour?’, ‘How likely would you say it is that [the perpetrator] could lead a productive life?’, ‘How likely would you say it is that [the perpetrator] could be rehabilitated?’ and ‘how likely is it that [the perpetrator] would commit a future offence?’ (reverse scored). These are all tested on a Likert scale from 1-5. 

Finally, to assess social distance 5 questions will be combined into an overall social distance score. The 5 questions are: ‘How likely would you be to rent housing to [the perpetrator]?’, ‘How likely would you be to employ [the perpetrator]?’, ‘How comfortable would you be living in the same town as [the perpetrator]?’, ‘How comfortable would you be living on the same street as [the perpetrator]?’, ‘How comfortable would you be if a family member married [the perpetrator]?’. These are all tested on a Likert scale from 1-5. 

In order to do this, a new variable will be computed in each of these cases that represents the sum/total score for each participant on the items that are measured within that subscale. As mentioned above, items that measure something counter-indicative will be reverse coded to make low scores high and vice versa. In order to compute scale scores a syntax code will be used within SPSS. For example, the syntax to create a sum score for the ‘aggression’ subscale will be: COMPUTE S_aggression = SUM(aggressive, violent).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Demographics: 
Participant demographics will be examined by running a descriptive statistics procedure on SPSS. 
Age will be entered as a numerical digit, due to the questionnaire asking participants to enter their age in years (e.g. 30). 
Gender will be coded as: Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4.
Occupation is a dichotomous question asking participants if they have ever worked within the criminal justice system. This will be coded as: Yes = 1, No = 2.
This procedure will be run by utilising the descriptive statistics procedure, producing N, minimum, maximum, mean, and standard deviation for these measures. 

For all multiple regression analyses, preliminary tests will be conducted to ensure data meet assumptions.

Emotion-rating scales: 
This emotion-rating scale will be used to assess emotions towards the perpetrator described in the vignette. 
There are 5 questions in this measure. The 2 questions that will be analysed are those that ask participants how much pity and anger they feel towards the perpetrator, the other 3 questions are filler questions that won’t be included in the analysis. Anger is hypothesised to represent contemptuous prejudice and pity is hypothesised to represent paternalistic prejudice (Clow and Leach, 2015). 
A hierarchical multiple regression will be conducted in order to analyse this data. 
The dependent variable will be ratings of anger and ratings of pity. 
The independent variables will be upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4). The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 1). 
The reasoning for using a multiple regression here is based on the ability to explore how a set of variables is able to predict the outcome as a whole as well as the relative contribution of each variable. Demographic variables such as participant age and gender are included due to multiple regression allowing such variables to be statistically controlled for within the model. Each independent variable will be assessed on what it adds to the prediction of the outcome variable.
As per hypothesis 1, it is expected that participants will rate the individual described as a looked-after child more negatively on emotion-rating scales (more anger and less pity towards them).

Stereotypes: 
This measure is split into 3 sub-tests measuring aggression, competency and warmth.
A hierarchical multiple regression will be conducted to assess the influence of a set of independent variables on perceptions of warmth, competency, and aggression.
The dependent variable here will be sum scores of warmth, competency, and aggression.
Independent variables will be upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4). 
The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 1). 
As per hypothesis 1, it is expected that participants will view the looked-after child as less warm, less competent and more aggressive.

Responsibility: 
The 4 questions in this measure will be averaged for an overall responsibility score. 
A hierarchal multiple regression will be conducted to assess the influence of a set of independent variables on judgements of overall responsibility (the dependent variable). The independent variables will be upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4). 
The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing and participant occupation will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 2 and 4). 
As per hypothesis 2, it is expected the individual described as a looked-after child will be deemed more responsible for the described crime. As predicted in hypothesis 4, it is also expected that participants with experience working in the criminal justice system will deem the perpetrator as less responsible.

Rehabilitation and discrimination: 
Potential for rehabilitation is measured by 4 questions (1. how likely is the perpetrator to outgrow their behaviour, 2. how likely is it the perpetrator will lead a productive life, 3. how likely is the perpetrator to be rehabilitated, 4. how likely is the perpetrator to commit a future offence). This will be averaged into a single index in which high scores indicate a high potential for rehabilitation (question 4 will be reverse scored). This will be the dependent variable.
This will then be assessed using a hierarchical multiple regression to explore the influence of upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4).
The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing and participant occupation will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 2 and 4). 
As per hypothesis 2, it is expected that the individual described as a looked-after child will be deemed less capable of rehabilitation. Furthermore, as per hypothesis 4, it is also expected participants with experience working in the criminal justice system will believe more so in the potential for rehabilitation.

Participant’s choice of sentence for the perpetrator in the vignette will then be predicted from the type of upbringing that is described and the participant’s occupation. This will be done using a forward stepwise logistic regression (binary logistic function in SPSS). The research question here would thus be to explore what factors predict the likelihood that respondents would assign rehabilitative/ punitive sentencing. 
The dependent variable here will be the question, ‘Would you be more likely to support punitive or rehabilitative measures for [the perpetrator]?’, in which participants have a binary response of ‘punitive’ or ‘rehabilitative’. 
The two independent variables will be perpetrator upbringing (looked-after child = 1, family raised = 2) and participant occupation (criminal justice experience = 1, no criminal justice experience = 2). 
As per hypothesis 2, it is expected that the perpetrator described as a looked-after child will be more likely to receive punitive action. Furthermore, as per hypothesis 4, it is expected that participants with experience working in the criminal justice system will be less likely to assign punitive measures to both groups. 

Social distance:
Social distance is measured by 5 questions which will be combined into an overall social distance score (higher scores indicate participants being more comfortable to the perpetrator). 
A hierarchical multiple regression will be conducted to assess the influence of a range of independent variables on the outcome variable (overall social distance score). 
The independent variables here will include upbringing (whether a perpetrator was described as a looked-after child or raised in a family setting- defined as 1 and 2 respectively), participant occupation (does the participant have experience working in the criminal justice system - Yes = 1, No = 2), participant age (in years) and participant gender (Male = 1, Female = 2, Rather not say = 3, Other = 4). 
The latter 2 variables will be entered in a first block, whilst participant occupation and perpetrator upbringing will be entered subsequently. The reasoning for this is to avoid indiscriminateness and also due to research suggesting that age and gender are often not significant predictors in research about public opinion. For example, Katz et al. (2008) found no effect of age on participant judgements of offenders, whereas Clow and Leach (2015), Katz et al. (2008) and Brown (1999) found no significant effect of gender. This assumption was also made due to it being hypothesized that perpetrator upbringing will be more predictive of the dependent variable (as per hypothesis 3). 
As per hypothesis 3, it is expected that participants will report being less comfortable with measures of social distance for the looked-after child.
